These findings extend to cohorts with established CV disease. Studying only patients with dilated cardiomyopathy, La Rovere and colleagues found reductions in HRV to be predictive of sudden death.[6] A resting ECG of 8 minutes’ duration was obtained with spontaneous respiration, as well as a controlled breathing period. Patients with dilated cardiomyopathy were found to have reductions in low frequency (LF) power with spontaneous (30 ms[2] versus 45 ms[2], p=0.01) and controlled-breathing (28 ms[2] versus 41 ms[2], p=0.02). Reduced LF power during controlled breathing was found to be predictive of sudden death during a 3-year follow-up period (RR 2.8, 95% CI [1.2–6.8]), independent of left ventricular dimensions.

Resting HRV measurements have been used to link enhanced sympathetic autonomic nervous system (SANS) activity with myocardial destabilisation and arrhythmogenic potential. HRV, however, serves as an indirect measurement of SANS, given its action on baroreceptors and the sinoatrial node. Periodic repolarisation dynamics (PRD), which can be obtained by focusing on low-frequency patterns of resting 3D ECGs, may serve as a more direct measurement.[7] Factors that lead to heterogeneous sympathetic activation, such as previous MI, diabetes, and inherited channelopathies, are all associated with greater PRD at rest. Previous studies have shown resting PRD to predict post-MI mortality independent of established risk factors such as left ventricular ejection fraction, the Global Registry of Acute Coronary Events (GRACE) score, increased QT-variability index, and reduced HRV.[8] Current studies are ongoing to better understand the role of PRD in identifying patients for prophylactic ICD placement.

### Ambulatory ECG for HRV Prognosis

While the ECG is the established gold standard for cardiac monitoring, technological advances have allowed for commercial products to be developed to allow for out-of-hospital monitoring. Both ECG and photo-based plethysmography have been validated as accurate measures of HR, and commercial products using these methods of detection have allowed for accurate and prolonged detection of arrhythmias such as AF.[9] With increasing evidence for HRV as a prognostic tool, there have been attempts to validate these home-based technologies for HRV as well.

Studying patients from the original Framingham study, Tsuji et al found an increased risk of all-cause mortality in patients with depressed HRV.[10] Using 2-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring, the investigators considered 736 patients from the original Framingham study. They found that, with adjustment for age, sex, and clinical risk factors, patients 1 SD below the mean for SD of NN intervals (SDNN), LF, very LF (VLF), HF and total power all had increased risks of all-cause mortality over 4 years. SDNN was the only time-domain factor with elevated risk after adjustment (HR 1.38, 95 % CI [1.13–1.70], p=0.019). Decreased values of LF were associated with highest adjusted risk (1.70, 95 % CI [1.37–2.09], p=0.001) of all HRV parameters. Additionally, a study combining patients from the original Framingham study and the Framingham Offspring Study (n=2,501, average age 53 years), demonstrated that with 2-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring, patients with lower SDNN had significantly higher rates of heart disease (12.40 versus 2.06).[11]

A long-term prospective study by Kikuya reported results from ambulatory BP data obtained from 1,542 subjects (mean 62 years, 40 % male) in Japan.[12] BP and HR measurements were taken every 30 minutes using an ambulatory cuff-oscillometric device, as the patients went about their normal day and night routines. Patients were divided by SDNN into three groups (mean - SD, mean ± SD, mean + SD) for analysis. A significant inverse linear relationship was noted for daytime HRV and cardiovascular death (p=0.008) during the mean follow-up period of 8.5 years, even after adjustment for use of beta blockers. The lowest HRV tertile was found to have HR of 3.64 (p=0.02). Changes in night-time HRV did not show a similar risk of CV death.

The Autonomic Tone and Reflexes After MI (ATRAMI) study considered the prognostic value of SDNN in 1,284 patients with recent MI.[13] Patients with MI within the previous 28 days were enrolled in the study and followed with ambulatory Holter monitoring for SDNN analysis. Baroreflex sensitivity was also assessed by measuring rate-pressure response to. infusion of phenylephrine. Multivariate analysis showed that patients with SDNN <70 ms or baroreflex sensitivity <3 ms/mmHg showed increased risk of cardiac mortality. In patients with depression of both parameters, 2-year mortality was 17 % compared with 2 % in patients where the parameters had remained stable. Klieger et al. demonstrated similar post-MI results,with a RR of mortality of 5.3 in post-MI patients with SDNN <50ms compared with those that had >100 ms.[14] The Gruppo Italiano per lo Studio della Sopravvivenza nell’Infarto Miocardico (GISSI-2) study analysed the usefulness of HRV in patients who had a recent MI that had been treated with fibrinolytic therapy.[15] Of 567 patients, 7.8 % died of cardiovascular causes during 1,000 days of follow-up. HRV parameters exhibited elevated RR for SDNN (RR 3.0), RMSSD (RR 2.8) and NN50 (RR 3.5).

While often used to predict mortality, a review by Reed et al looked at HRV as a predictor of ventricular tachyarrhythmias (VTA).[16] Vybrial et al showed no consistent changes in HRV indices in 24 patients who wore Holter monitors and developed ventricular fibrillation.[17] Huikuri et al, however, found significant reductions in HR and HRV indices (SDANN, HF, LF) in post-MI patients who developed ventricular tachycardia compared with those without arrhythmic events.[18] These changes occurred in the 1-hour period preceding VTA, and the degree of reduction was more pronounced in patients with sustained arrhythmias. Shusterman et al demonstrated that the presence of a change in HRV alone,[19] within a 2-hour period before arrhythmic events, could predict the development of VTAs.[20]

Focusing on patients with an ejection fraction lower than 35%, New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class III or IV, and QRS duration >130 ms, Adamson and colleagues sought to assess the feasibility of implantable cardiac resynchronisation devices for prognostic purposes in an ambulatory setting.[21] Using atrial intervals, HRV was defined as the standard deviation of median 5-minute a-a intervals over each 24-hour period (SDAAM). They found that the patients with the lowest SDAAM (<50 ms) had the highest all-cause mortality (HR 3.2, p=0.02) and CV-related death (HR 4.4, p=0.01) compared with higher SDAAM values over a 12-month follow-up period. Additionally, absolute SDAAM values were lower in the inpatients who were included in the study.

The Multicenter Automatic Defibrillator Implantation Trial-Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (MADIT-CRT) trial followed patients with ejection fraction lower than 30 %, QRS duration >130 ms, and non-ischaemic heart failure with NYHA functional class I or II, randomising them to either cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT-D) or ICD alone.[22] In a retrospective analysis of these patients, Sharazi et al found that patients in the lowest tertile of SDNN (≤93 ms) had higher rates of death or heart failure (24 % versus 17 %, p=0.004).[22] Similar outcomes were shown using frequency domain measures such as VLF (28 % versus 14 %, p<0.001). The overall results agreed with the UK Heart Failure Evaluation and Assessment of Risk Trial (UK-Heart) trial, which showed increased risk of death in patients with heart failure and depressed SDNN values.[20] In their sub-study analysis, the MADIT-CRT investigators concluded that ambulatory HRV analysis in heart failure patients may identify patients who would most benefit from CRT; low HRV showed no benefit with CRT-D versus ICD alone, while patients with preserved HRV treated with CRT-D had a lower risk of death. It appears that not only can HRV be used to assess the risk of death and hospitalisation in patients with heart failure, but it may also be used to determine candidates for CRT-D therapy.

### Exercise HRV and Prognosis

In the first study of exercise, HRV and prognosis, Dewey and colleagues performed time and frequency-domain HRV analysis on R-R interval data taken from 1,335 subjects (95% male; mean age 58 years) during the first and last 2 minutes of treadmill testing and the first 2 minutes of recovery.[23] Cox survival analysis was performed for the 53 cardiovascular and 133 all-cause deaths that accrued during the 5-year mean follow-up. After adjusting for potential confounders, greater root mean square successive difference in R-R interval during peak exercise and recovery, greater HF power and percentage of HF power, lower percentage of LF power, and lower ratio of LF to HF during recovery were significantly associated with increased risks for all-cause and CV death. Of all time-domain variables considered, the log of the root mean square successive difference during recovery was the strongest predictor of CV mortality (adjusted HR 5.0, 95 % CI [1.5–17.0]) for the top quintile compared with the lowest quintile). Log HF power during recovery was the strongest predictor of CV mortality in the frequency domain (adjusted HR 5.9, 95 % CI [1.3–25.8], for the top quintile compared with the lowest quintile). They concluded that exercise-induced HRV variables during and after clinical exercise testing strongly predict both CV and all-cause mortality independent of clinical factors and exercise responses in a clinical population.

Despite the strong association found in the study by Dewey et al., other investigators, such as Nieminen et al., have argued that these findings may be predominantly driven by heart rate alone.[23,24] As HRV is associated with HR physiologically (autonomic system) and mathematically (R-R interval), further consideration of this relationship is required to integrate these variables in risk stratification. Pradhapan and colleagues explored this by assessing the effect of HR correction on pre- and post-exercise HRV.[25] They selected 1,288 patients from the Finnish Cardiovascular Study cohort. Inclusion criteria included completing a maximum effort exercise test and good quality HRV measurement for at least 2 minutes during rest, immediately before exercise and during post-exercise recovery. All participants were followed for cardiac and non-cardiac mortality for a mean time of 54 months. The investigators concluded that exercise-induced HRV parameters (RMSSD, VLF power, LF power, p<0.001 pre- and post-exercise) strongly predict cardiac morality with similar but weaker association found for non-cardiac mortality. Consistent with contemporary data presented by Sacha et al, they showed that when predicting both cardiac and non-cardiac morality, weakening HRV dependence on HR at rest improved prognostic capacity.[26] Future studies are required to quantify the clinical significance of HRV recorded during exercise with a different HR and respiratory rate.

## Rest and Exercise HRV for Training

The use of HRV as a tool to track and monitor the status of athletes has gained much interest over recent years.[27] The desire to be the best often pushes the athlete to the fine line between the maximisation of effective training (achieved by duration, frequency and intensity) and ineffective training (e.g. maladaptation, non-functional overreaching and overtraining).[28] Given the fact that adaptive responses to a training load or stimulus are individual,[29–31] it is understandable that the ability to independently assess positive or negative training adaptation would be advantageous to athletes, sport scientists and coaches alike.

### HRV and Training Maladaptation

The hypothesis behind the early detection of non-functional overreaching (NFOR) or overtraining (OT) and fatigue is the possibility of assuring adequate recovery through specified rest between training. By allowing recovery based on the constantly changing dynamic of the athlete and the amount of further training needed, the recovery optimises future performance. The performance begins to decline if the recovery is not adequate, resulting in a continuum from functional overreaching (F-OR), NFOR, OT and, eventually, overtraining syndrome (OTS).[32]

In athletes, changes in the patterns of their autonomic nervous system (ANS) reflected by altered HRV may serve as useful objective parameters for managing their physical fatigue. Information regarding the extent to which the body recovers after training may provide useful data to avoid NFOR, OT and OTS. Many studies have examined HRV and overtraining have revealed ambivalent findings, with increases, decreases, and no change in HRV reported (*Table 4*).[33–36] In one case study, a junior skier with reported OT had a substantially increased HRV and the values subsequently decreases once the athlete had undergone a recovery period.[34] Conversely, Mourot et al.[37] showed that overtraining was associated with decreased HRV. Seven athletes had endurance training and had been clinically diagnosed with OTS. However, given the continuum from F-OR to OTS, and the difficulty in deciphering between stages, these differences observed may be due to inconsistencies in the accurate diagnosis of the fatigue stage.[38,39] This may be one of the reasons why more recent studies have focused on F-OR rather than NFOR and OT,which can be quantified by decreases and subsequent increases in performance (after a taper period).[38,40–42] Accordingly, these data demonstrate the importance of understanding where each athlete sits on this continuum of fatigue (F-OR→NFOR→OT→OTS). Such knowledge is critical for the accurate interpretation of HRV results to regulate athlete training.

### HRV and Training Adaptation

Endurance training elicits marked changes in cardiorespiratory function in both sedentary and active individuals, concomitant to changes in cardiac vagal activity, as evidenced by reduced resting and exercise HR.[46] As such, the individualised nature of changes in HRV is fundamental to its use as a marker of training adaptation.[47]

The changes in HRV in response to endurance training programmes have been extensively studied (*Table 5*). In people who have been sedentary or who have trained recreationally, endurance training for 2, 6 and 9 weeks has been shown to induce parallel increases in aerobic fitness and HRV.[45,48,49] For example, previously sedentary men completed 9 weeks of intensive endurance training followed by 4 weeks of overload training and had large increases in maximal aerobic capacity (+20 %) and vagal-related HRV (+67 %).[50] While this is the response typically seen in sedentary and recreationally trained people after a period of endurance training, the response in people who have an extensive training history can be decidedly different. In these athletes, the HRV response to training is inconsistent, with longitudinal studies showing no change in fitness (VO~2~ max uptake) despite increases in HRV, and cross-sectional studies showing lower HRV in association with superior fitness.[52,52] In elite distance runners training for 18 weeks (6 weeks moderately intensive and 12 weeks intensive) culminating in a half marathon or marathon, there was no change in VO~2~ max, but a 45 % increase in HRV.[45] Conversely, in 55 young male soccer players, lower HRV was associated with higher VO~2~ max and maximum aerobic speed.[49]

Plews et al. used data from elite rowers at the Olympics.[53] They showed a consistent HRV trend before peak performance, with substantial increases in HRV (above baseline) before a decline to baseline values as the competition approached (during a taper period).Such trends have since been validated in experimental studies by both Le Meur et al. and Bellenger et al. with athletes functionally adapting to training (F-OR).[41,44] Le Meur et al. showed that triathletes who responded positively to 3 weeks of overload training had substantial increases in RMSSD (96 % chance of an HRV increase) followed by reductions to baseline after a 1-week taper. Those classified in the F-OR had large increases in running performance over an incremental running rest (effect size 1.17 ± 0.22). Similarly, Bellenger et al showed HRV increases in triatheletes (effect size = 0.62 ± 0.26) after a 2-week heavy training period. These increases were reduced after a 10-day taper which coincided with improved 5 km running time trial performance (effect size -0.34 ± 0.08). Importantly, in both these studies, there were observed reductions in performance after the training overload period, when HRV was substantial higher. Accordingly, in such cases, increases in HRV are indicative of coping with intensified training (i.e. F-OR), not increases in performance. Improved performance was only observed after the taper period when HRV had reduced back towards baseline levels.

Taking these data into account, it has been suggested that there is a bell-shaped relationship between vagally related HRV and fitness/performance.[49] This, to some extent, may also be due to HRV saturation which is often seen in athletes with extensive training histories and low resting heart rates.[54]

### Using HRV to Guide Training

Given the usability of HRV to track training adaptations, it could be used as a tool to guide daily training. Three studies have shown training guided by the daily recordings of HRV to be superior (at increasing fitness and exercise performance) to training based on conventional methods.[55–57]

Recently, Vesterinen et al. investigated the effectiveness of using HRV to prescribe training on a day-to-day basis.[57] Forty recreational endurance runners were divided into the HRV-guided experimental training group (EXP) and traditional pre-defined training (TRAD). After a 4-week preparation training period, the TRAD group trained according to a predefined training programme including two-to-three moderate (MOD) and high-intensity training (HIT) sessions per week during an 8-week intensive training period. The timing of MOD and HIT sessions in EXP was based on HRV measured every morning. RMSSD was used to prescribe training because of its greater reliability than other HRV spectral indices.[58] A 7-day rolling average of RMSSD was calculated because it has been proposed to be more sensitive to track changes in the training status compared with single-day values.[53] The MOD/HIT session was programmed if HRV was within an individually determined smallest change. Otherwise, low-intensity training was performed. VO~2~ max and 3,000 m running performance were measured before and after both training periods. The number of MOD and HIT sessions was significantly lower (p=0.021, effect size 0.98) in the EXP group (13.2 ± 6.0 sessions) compared with TRAD (17.7 ± 2.5 sessions). No other differences in training were found between the groups. The 3,000 m run time improved in EXP (2.1 % T 2.0 %, p=0.004) but not in the TRAD group (1.1 % T 2.7 %, p=0.118) during the intensive training period. A small but clear between-group difference (effect size = 0.42) was found in the change in running performance over 3,000 m. VO~2~ max improved in both groups (EXP: 3.7 %, ± 4.6 %, p=0.027; TRAD: 5.0 % ± 5.2 %, p=0.002). They concluded that there was potential in using resting HRV to prescribe endurance training by individualising the timing of vigorous training sessions.

Two studies by Kiviniemi et al. also showed superior responses to training when guided by daily HRV, similar to Vesterinen et al.[55–57] Greater improvements in VO~2~ max and maximal attainable workload[56] in groups of trained subjects who performed high-intensity training when morning resting HRV was high, and low-intensity training when these values were low. This was despite the HRV-guided training group performing HIT sessions less frequently than a traditional training group (average three compared with 4-hour HIT sessions per week). Hence, adaptation was improved when lower intensity training was completed when vagal modulation of HR was attenuated.

A study from 2018 split 17 well-trained cyclists into two groups.[59] Group one followed a training plan guided by morning resting HRV (HRV-G, n=9), whereas group 2 followed a more traditional approach (TRAD, n=8). Following a similar design to Kiviniemi, on days when the 7-day rolling average of RMSSD fell outside the predetermined individual smallest range, the HRV-G training group would carry out low intensity training or rest rather than moderate-intensity training or HIT.[55] The TRAD group’s training regimens included scheduled low-intensity, moderate-intensity, HIT and high-intensity interval training. There were no statistical differences in volume or intensity distribution in either group during the experimental period. Although there were no between-group differences, the HRV-G group substantially increased in peak power output (5.1 ± 4.5 %; p=0.024), upper threshold power (13.9 ± 8.8 %; p=0.004) and 40 km time trial performance (7.3 ± 4.5 %; p=0.005). The TRAD group did not improve significantly in any of these performance measures after their training period. This again supports the possible efficacy of HRV-G training being a suitable method to enhance training adaptations in athletes.

Methodological considerations are important when using HRV to monitor training in athletes. However, it is generally accepted that reductions in HRV are associated with negative performance outcomes, and increases associated with a positive response to higher training loads (*Tables 4 and 5*). However, such changes must be taken within the context of the training phase (i.e heavy training versus taper), and fitness status of the individual.[60] Both supportive and opposing views have been highlighted in a recent HRV and exercise training meta-analysis by Bellenger et al.[61] The aim of this meta-analysis was to interpret how vagally derived indices of HR could be used to inform training decisions. Focusing on HRV only here, they suggested that improved exercise performance was associated with increases in resting RMSSD (effect size = 0.58). However, there was also a small increase in resting RMSSD (effect size = 0.26) associated with decreases in performance. This supports the idea that, although HRV measures can be useful, they should still be used alongside other measures of training tolerance to aid decision-making.

## Conclusions

The past decade has shown that HRV provides valuable prognostic information that can contribute to risk scores and cardiac variables such as echocardiographic measurements and exercise capacity. There is strong evidence to suggest that elevated HRV has a protective effect against CV disease. Conversely, exercise and HRV show the opposite relationship. Greater HRV during recovery from exercise is associated with an increased risk of all-cause and cardiovascular death. However, other investigators have argued that these findings may be predominantly driven by heart rate alone and further research is required in this area. Over more recent years, the area of HRV and athlete monitoring has been investigated. It is now generally accepted that substantial reductions in HRV are associated with negative adaptations to training and HRV increases are associated with positive adaptations, with an inverted U shape being the optimal trend in HRV in athletes before they reach peak performance. Furthermore, studies that have based daily training sessions on morning resting HRV values have had mostly positive outcomes.

In the era of wearable monitoring devices and increased interest in personalised approaches to lifestyle modification, HRV may provide useful information to direct lifestyle change, guide exercise regimens and monitor for over-training. Given the advancement in wearable HRV recording devices, research is needed to understand the complex relationships between physiology and performance and day-to-day trends. Furthermore, future population studies are needed to assess the potential of HRV information acquired through wearable devices which use photo-based plethysmography and ECG technology and validate its value as a prognostic marker.

### Clinical Perspective
- Resting, exercise and ambulatory heart rate variability (HRV) measure­ments are useful for predicting cardiovascular risk.
- The use of mHealth technologies allows acceptable ambulatory detection of HRV compared with traditional ECG methods.
- The data behind using ambulatory HRV to guide or structure athletic training programmes are limited, but there is a possible benefit in using HRV to optimise performance and prevent over-training

## HYROX Sled Push weight

The HYROX sled push is a major strength test. Athletes push a sled over 50 meters (2 x 25m), with weights stacked depending on the division.

The listed weight includes the sled (usually ~30–40 kg) plus added plates.

**Open Women**: 102 kg **Pro Women**: 152 kg **Open Men**: 152 kg **Pro Men**: 202 kg

Tip: Traction and pushing form matter more than brute strength.

## HYROX Sled Pull weight

The HYROX sled pull station uses the same sled as the sled push, but now you're pulling it 50 meters (2 x 25m) with arm and back strength.

The weights are slightly lower than the sled push.

**Open Women**: 78 kg **Pro Women**: 103 kg **Open Men**: 103 kg **Pro Men**: 153 kg

Train with heavy rope pulls and seated row variations.

## Farmers Carry HYROX Weights

You’ll carry two kettlebells or dumbbells over a 200 meter course.

Core and grip endurance are key for the HYROX farmers carry.

**Open Women**: 2 × 16 kg **Pro Women**: 2 × 24 kg **Open Men**: 2 × 24 kg **Pro Men**: 2 × 32 kg

Pro tip: Keep shoulders back and walk tall to avoid fatigue.

## HYROX Lunge weight

This 100-meter walking HYROX lunge with a sandbag on your back will test your legs and mental focus late in the race.

**Open Women**: 10 kg **Pro Women**: 20 kg **Open Men**: 20 kg **Pro Men**: 30 kg

No dropping of the sandbag, try to make it one continuous effort.

## HYROX Wall Ball weight

The race ends with HYROX wall balls: squat and throw to a target.

The weight and rep count depend on your category.

**Open Women**: 100 reps with 4 kg to a 2.70 m target **Pro Women**: 100 reps with 6 kg to a 2.70 m target **Open Men**: 100 reps with 6 kg to a 3 m target **Pro Men**: 100 reps with 9 kg to a 3 m target

Accuracy and pacing are critical here.

## HYROX Cardio Standards: Running, SkiErg & RowErg

While these HYROX stations don’t have weights, they’re just as crucial for your performance:

**HYROX SkiErg**: 1000 meters **HYROX RowErg**: 1000 meters **HYROX Running**: 8 × 1,000 meters (one run between every station)

These distances are the same across all divisions (Open and Pro, men and women).

To perform well at the HYROX event, you’ll need to move efficiently on each machine and pace your runs wisely. The perfect balance to perform as a great hybrid athlete.

**SkiErg focus**: Smooth pulls, consistent breathing **RowErg focus**: Strong drive, relaxed return **Running focus**: Recovery pace early, acceleration in later rounds

## Why HYROX weights matter

Training with the official HYROX weights is non-negotiable if you want to perform well on race day.

Each station places a unique demand on your body, from explosive sled pushes to endurance-driven wall balls. Check out our quick links for HYROX weights:

# HYROX AI Coach: Autoregulation & Adaptive Programming Framework

> **Version:** 2.0 · **Effective:** February 2026
> **Purpose:** This document defines every decision rule, threshold, and communication template the AI coach uses to modify the 16-week Hyrox periodization plan in real time. It is the system's adaptive intelligence layer—no rule may output vague language such as "adjust accordingly."

---

## 1. RPE-Based Session Modification Rules

### 1.1 Pre-Session Readiness Check

Before every session, the AI coach asks the athlete five standardized questions, each scored 1–10. The composite **Readiness Score** is the equally weighted average of all five sub-scores, rounded to one decimal place. Research supports multi-dimensional subjective wellness questionnaires as superior predictors of training tolerance compared with objective measures alone (Saw, Main & Gastin, 2016, *BJSM*; Thorpe et al., 2017, *IJSPP*).

| # | Readiness Question | Anchors (1 = worst, 10 = best) |
|---|---|---|
| 1 | **Sleep Quality** — "Rate your sleep last night." | 1 = ≤4 hrs or constantly waking; 5 = ~6 hrs, average quality; 10 = 8+ hrs, deep, uninterrupted |
| 2 | **Muscle Soreness** — "How sore are you right now?" | 1 = severe pain / cannot move freely; 5 = moderate tightness; 10 = no soreness at all |
| 3 | **Motivation** — "How eager are you to train today?" | 1 = dreading it; 5 = neutral; 10 = fired up |
| 4 | **Life Stress** — "Rate your mental/emotional stress." | 1 = extreme stress/crisis; 5 = manageable; 10 = totally calm |
| 5 | **Nutrition / Hydration** — "How well did you eat and hydrate in the past 24 hours?" | 1 = missed meals, dehydrated; 5 = okay; 10 = dialed in |

**Readiness Score = (Q1 + Q2 + Q3 + Q4 + Q5) / 5**

### 1.2 Readiness Tier Decision Table

| Readiness Score | Tier Label | Session Modification |
|---|---|---|
| **8.0–10.0** | 🟢 **Green — Execute** | Run session exactly as programmed. If athlete has been in Green for 5+ consecutive sessions and RPE stays ≤6, flag for potential under-programming (see Rule CR-2). |
| **6.0–7.9** | 🟡 **Yellow — Modify** | Reduce **total volume by 20%** (cut lowest-priority sets/intervals first). Maintain programmed intensity. If the session is HIIT, remove the final 1–2 rounds. If the session is strength, drop the last accessory exercise and reduce main-lift sets by 1. If the session is running, shorten distance by 20% but keep target pace. |
| **4.0–5.9** | 🟠 **Orange — Significant Modification** | Reduce **volume by 40%** AND reduce **intensity by 10–15%** (drop pace targets by 10–15 sec/km; drop strength loads by 10–15%). Convert any HIIT session to a moderate-intensity continuous session (Zone 2 run + bodyweight movement flow for 25–35 min). Cap session duration at 40 minutes. |
| **1.0–3.9** | 🔴 **Red — Recovery Session** | Replace planned session with one of the following: (a) 20-min walk + 15-min mobility/foam rolling, (b) 20-min easy swim or bike at HR <120 bpm + 10-min breathwork/meditation, (c) Full rest day with guided stretching video (15 min). Log as "recovery replacement." Re-assess readiness next day. If athlete scores Red 2+ consecutive days, trigger Overtraining Investigation Protocol (see Rule CR-13). |

### 1.3 During-Session RPE Monitoring

The AI coach requests RPE checks at three points within each session. RPE is collected on the standard Borg CR-10 scale, validated for both resistance training (Zourdos et al., 2016, *JSCR*) and endurance exercise (Foster et al., 2001, *JSCR*).

#### 1.3.1 Post-Warm-Up Check (after first 8–10 minutes)

| Warm-Up RPE | Expected RPE | Action |
|---|---|---|
| ≤5 | 3–5 | ✅ Proceed as planned. |
| 6 | 3–5 | ⚠️ Note elevated effort. Extend warm-up by 5 min of easy movement. Re-check. If RPE drops to ≤5 → proceed. If RPE stays ≥6 → downgrade session by one tier (e.g., Green → Yellow modifications). |
| 7+ | 3–5 | 🛑 Downgrade session by **two tiers** (e.g., Green → Orange). If warm-up RPE ≥ 8 → convert entire session to recovery (Red tier). Log event and flag for pattern tracking. |

#### 1.3.2 Mid-Session Check (at session midpoint)

| Mid-Session RPE vs. Target | Action |
|---|---|
| Within ±1 of target | ✅ Continue as planned. |
| 1.5–2 points above target | Reduce remaining volume by 25%. Extend rest periods by 30 seconds between sets/intervals. |
| >2 points above target | **End high-intensity work immediately.** Complete 5-min cool-down at RPE ≤3. Log as "session cut short — elevated RPE." Attribute remaining volume as missed and apply Missed Session Logic (Section 2) at the 1-session level. |
| 2+ points below target | Add 1–2 additional rounds/sets (up to 15% extra volume) OR increase pace/load by 5% for remaining work. |

#### 1.3.3 Post-Session RPE (sRPE — Session RPE)

Collected 15–30 minutes after session completion per Foster et al. (2001) methodology. **sRPE × session duration (min) = session load (AU).**

| Data Point | How It's Used |
|---|---|
| sRPE logged | Stored in 7-day rolling average. Compared to programmed target RPE. |
| sRPE × duration = load (AU) | Acute load (7-day sum) and chronic load (28-day average) tracked. Acute:Chronic Workload Ratio (ACWR) calculated weekly. |
| ACWR 0.8–1.3 | ✅ Training load in safe zone (Gabbett, 2016, *BJSM*). |
| ACWR >1.5 | 🛑 Spike detected — reduce next 3 sessions by 20% volume. |
| ACWR <0.7 | ⚠️ Detraining risk — increase next week's volume by 10–15%. |

### 1.4 Cross-Session Adaptation Rules (CR Rules)

These 18 if/then rules fire automatically based on accumulated session data. Each rule references specific thresholds, session types, and corrective actions.

#### Fatigue & Overload Rules

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-1** | RPE > 8 on 2 consecutive HIIT sessions | Reduce next HIIT session volume by 25% (remove final 2 rounds). Insert 1 additional Zone 2 run (30–40 min, RPE 3–4) before the next HIIT session. |
| **CR-2** | RPE < 5 on 3 consecutive sessions of any type | Increase intensity by 5–10% (add 5–10 sec/km to pace targets, or 5–10% to strength loads) OR add 1 additional set/round to the next 2 sessions. |
| **CR-3** | RPE ≥ 9 on any "easy" session (programmed target RPE ≤5) | Flag **overtraining investigation**: prompt athlete for illness symptoms, check 7-day sleep average, review preceding 14-day training load. If sleep avg < 6 hrs → trigger lifestyle intervention (Section 5). If no lifestyle explanation → insert 2 consecutive rest days and reduce following week volume by 30%. |
| **CR-4** | RPE > 8 on 3 out of 4 strength sessions within a 2-week block | Reduce strength training loads by 10% for the next mesocycle. Add 1 extra rest day between strength sessions. If within 4 weeks of competition, convert one strength session per week to strength-endurance (lighter load, higher rep, circuit format). |
| **CR-5** | RPE < 4 on 2 consecutive strength sessions | Increase working loads by 5–7.5% on main lifts (squat, deadlift, bench press, overhead press). Keep accessory volumes unchanged. |

#### Running-Specific Rules

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-6** | Running RPE > planned RPE by ≥2 points on 2 out of 3 runs in a week | Reduce next week's total running volume by 15–20%. Convert 1 interval/tempo run to a Zone 2 easy run. Review shoe condition and check for injury signs. |
| **CR-7** | Running RPE consistently 1–2 points below target for ≥2 weeks | Advance running pace targets by 5 sec/km. If the athlete is in General Prep, consider moving to Specific Prep running intensities early. |
| **CR-8** | Athlete reports RPE ≥ 8 on ≥3 of the 8 running segments during a simulation | Identify which running segments (early vs. late) are most affected. If segments 5–8 are elevated → increase long-run volume by 10% and add a second Zone 2 run per week. If segments 1–3 are elevated → athlete is starting too fast; prescribe pacing drill with negative-split structure. |

#### HIIT & Simulation-Specific Rules

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-9** | Average HIIT sRPE over 4-week block exceeds programmed target by >1 point | Reduce HIIT density: increase work:rest ratio from 1:1 to 1:1.5, or from 1:0.5 to 1:1 for the next 2-week block. Maintain total session duration. |
| **CR-10** | Simulation sRPE ≥ 9 AND total sim time is >10% slower than goal pace | Add 1 half-simulation per week (4 stations + 4 × 1 km) at race pace for 3 weeks, focusing on the 4 weakest stations. Reduce full-simulation frequency to every 14 days instead of every 10 days. |
| **CR-11** | Simulation sRPE ≤ 6 AND total sim time is within 5% of goal pace | Athlete is ready for progression. Increase simulation specificity: add transition drills (Roxzone efficiency practice), and in the next full sim, attempt a 2–3% negative split in running segments. |

#### Deload & Recovery Triggers

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-12** | Average weekly Readiness Score drops below 6.0 for 2 consecutive weeks | Insert an **unscheduled deload week**: reduce all volumes by 40%, reduce all intensities by 15%, replace 1 HIIT session with Zone 2 cardio, add 1 full rest day. Resume normal programming after 7 days if Readiness returns to ≥7.0. |
| **CR-13** | Readiness Score ≤ 3.9 for 3+ consecutive days | Trigger **Overtraining Investigation Protocol**: (1) Suspend all training for 48 hours. (2) Request physician clearance if illness suspected. (3) On return, apply the "Miss a Full Week" protocol (Section 2.4). (4) Log incident for macro-cycle review. |
| **CR-14** | HRV 7-day rolling average drops >1 SD below personal baseline for ≥5 consecutive days (if wearable data available) | Reduce high-intensity sessions by 50% for the following week. Replace with Zone 1–2 aerobic work. This aligns with Plews et al. (2013) findings and Kiviniemi et al. (2007, 2010) HRV-guided training research showing improved adaptation when training is reduced during periods of attenuated vagal tone. |

#### Progressive Overload Guards

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-15** | Athlete completes all sessions in a week at programmed volume/intensity with average sRPE ≤ programmed target for 3 consecutive weeks | Auto-progress: increase running volume by 5–8%, HIIT rounds by 1, or strength loads by 2.5–5% in the following week. This aligns with DeLorme's (1946) original progressive overload principles and modern autoregulation research (Greig et al., 2020, *Sports Med*). |
| **CR-16** | Athlete's ACWR exceeds 1.3 for 2 consecutive weeks | Cap the following week's acute load to ≤1.2 × chronic load. Achieve this by removing the lowest-priority session of the week. |
| **CR-17** | Readiness Score ≥ 8 for 10+ consecutive sessions AND sRPE consistently ≤ 5 | Possible under-training. Increase weekly training frequency by 1 session (add a station-specific supplemental session) OR increase session density by 10%. Monitor for 2 weeks. |
| **CR-18** | Post-session RPE deviates from target RPE by >2 points (in either direction) on ≥50% of sessions in a 2-week block | Recalibrate athlete's RPE anchoring: provide RPE education refresher, re-assess training zones with a benchmark test. If calibration seems accurate, adjust the entire plan's target RPEs to match athlete's actual response curve. |

## 2. Missed Session Recovery Logic

### 2.1 Session Priority Hierarchy by Training Phase

Every session type carries a priority rank that dictates which sessions to protect when time is limited or sessions are missed.

| Priority | General Prep (Wk 1–4) | Specific Prep (Wk 5–8) | Competition Prep (Wk 9–14) | Taper (Wk 15–16) |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| 1 (Must-Do) | Long Run / Zone 2 Run | HIIT (Hyrox-style intervals) | Full/Half Simulation | Short High-Intensity Intervals (≤20 min) |
| 2 | HIIT (general conditioning) | Tempo/Threshold Run | HIIT (race-specific) | Easy Run (20–30 min) |
| 3 | Strength (full body) | Strength (functional) | Threshold Running | Mobility / Active Recovery |
| 4 | Mobility / Recovery | Mobility / Recovery | Strength (maintenance) | Everything else is optional |

### 2.2 Missed Session Decision Matrix

| Scenario | Decision Logic |
|---|---|
| **Miss 1 session in a week** | **Do NOT reschedule if it was Priority 3 or 4.** If Priority 1 or 2: compress into an adjacent day by combining it as a reduced-volume add-on (50% of original volume appended as a "bonus block" to the next session, adding ≤15 min). Never stack 2 full sessions on the same day. |
| **Miss 2 sessions in a week** | Protect the **top 2 priority sessions** for the current phase. Remove the lowest-priority remaining session. Redistribute: take the most important missed session and insert it at 75% volume on the nearest available day. Accept the second missed session as lost volume — do NOT chase it. |
| **Miss 3+ sessions (illness/travel)** | Stop chasing missed volume entirely. Re-enter training using the **Graduated Return Protocol** (Section 2.4). Assess Readiness Score on the first day back. If Readiness ≥ 7: resume at 70% of planned volume for 3 days, then 85% for 3 days, then 100%. If Readiness 5–6: resume at 50% volume for 4 days, then 70% for 3 days, then 85% for 3 days. |
| **Miss a full week** | Apply the **50/30/20/10 Return Rule** adapted from NSCA/CSCCa consensus guidelines: **Day 1–2:** 50% of normal session volume, RPE cap of 5. **Day 3–4:** 70% volume, RPE cap of 6. **Day 5–7:** 85% volume, RPE cap of 7. **Week 2:** 100% volume. No benchmark testing for ≥10 days post-return. This is supported by the graduated return-to-play protocols (Elliott et al., 2020, *BJSM*; NSCA/CSCCa Joint Guidelines). |
| **Miss 2+ weeks (injury/illness)** | Require medical clearance before resuming. On clearance: restart training at the **beginning of the previous mesocycle** at 50% volume. Progress per the 50/30/20/10 rule over 2 weeks. Reassess goal time and potentially extend the 16-week plan by the number of weeks missed. Retest all benchmarks at the 2-week post-return mark. |

### 2.3 "Which Sessions Can I Skip?" Quick Reference

| Session Type | Skip-able? | Consequence of Skipping |
|---|---|---|
| Full Simulation (Competition Prep) | ❌ Never skip | Reschedule within 3 days, even at reduced volume (half-sim) |
| HIIT — Race-Specific | ❌ Rarely skip | If must skip, replace with a 30-min threshold run to preserve metabolic stimulus |
| Long Run (>45 min) | ⚠️ Conditional | Can skip 1 per 3-week block; replace with 2 shorter Zone 2 runs |
| Strength — Main Lifts | ⚠️ Conditional | Can skip if already completed 1 strength session that week |
| Strength — Accessories | ✅ Yes | Lowest consequence; absorb into warm-up of next session as activation work |
| Easy Run / Recovery | ✅ Yes | Replace with walking or rest with zero guilt |

## 3. Time-Constrained Session Modifications

When an athlete reports they have less time than the planned session requires, the AI compresses the session according to the **"protect intensity, sacrifice volume"** principle (Helms et al., 2018, *JSCR*; Graham & Cleather, 2019).

### 3.1 Universal Compression Matrix

| Planned Duration | Available Time | Compression Level | General Rule |
|---|---|---|---|
| 60 min | **45 min** (75%) | Moderate | Cut warm-up to 5 min (from 10), cut cool-down to 3 min (from 7–10). Remove the lowest-priority element. Keep main set at full intensity and ≥75% of prescribed volume. |
| 60 min | **30 min** (50%) | Aggressive | Warm-up = 3 min only (dynamic). Cool-down = walk for 2 min. Execute **only the main set** at full intensity with 60% of prescribed volume. All accessories/supplementary work removed. |
| 60 min | **15 min** (25%) | Emergency Minimum | No formal warm-up (begin at 50% effort, ramp over 2 min). Execute the single highest-priority element at full intensity for the maximum possible work in 10 min. 3-min cool-down walk. Log as "emergency session." |

### 3.2 Compression Rules by Session Type

#### Running Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | Keep main interval/tempo set unchanged. Cut warm-up jog from 10 min to 5 min. Cut cool-down from 10 min to 5 min. Remove any strides/drills. |
| 30 min | 3-min warm-up jog → Execute main set at prescribed intensity (e.g., tempo or intervals) for 22 min → 5-min easy jog cool-down. If tempo run: maintain pace, shorten distance proportionally. |
| 15 min | 2-min build-up jog → 10 min at threshold pace (RPE 7–8) → 3-min walk. Preserves top-end aerobic stimulus. |

#### HIIT Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | Keep all prescribed movements. Reduce total rounds by 2 (e.g., 6 rounds → 4 rounds). Maintain prescribed work:rest ratio and intensity. |
| 30 min | Keep the 4 most Hyrox-relevant movements, remove any supplemental/accessory exercises. Perform 3 rounds at prescribed intensity. Rest periods shortened by 15 sec each. |
| 15 min | **"Hyrox Essentials" EMOM:** 10-min EMOM alternating between sled push simulation (30 sec max effort) and wall balls (20 reps) + 5-min cool-down. |

#### Strength Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | Keep all main compound lifts (squat, deadlift, press). Remove all accessories (curls, lateral raises, etc.). Keep programmed sets, reps, and loads for main lifts. |
| 30 min | Select the 2 most relevant main lifts (lower body + upper body). Perform programmed sets and loads. Superset where possible to save time. |
| 15 min | Perform 1 compound lift only (prioritize the weakest pattern). 3 working sets at programmed intensity. Example: 3 × 5 back squat at prescribed load. Done in <12 min. |

#### Simulation Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | **Half-simulation:** 4 × 1 km run + 4 stations. Select the 4 weakest stations based on most recent benchmark data. Execute at full race pace. |
| 30 min | **Quarter-simulation:** 2 × 1 km run + 2 stations (the 2 weakest). Full race effort. Plus 5-min cool-down jog. |
| 15 min | **Single-station drill:** 1 km run at race pace → 1 full station at race effort → 1 km run at race pace. Choose the single weakest station. |

## 4. Performance-Based Plan Adjustments

### 4.1 Benchmark Test Schedule

The AI coach schedules benchmark tests at the end of every 4-week block (Weeks 4, 8, 12, and 15 for final check).

| Benchmark Test | What It Measures | Protocol |
|---|---|---|
| 5 km Time Trial | Aerobic running fitness | Outdoor or treadmill, best effort, record time and average pace |
| Individual Station Tests | Station-specific performance | Each Hyrox station performed in isolation: SkiErg 1,000 m, Row 1,000 m, Sled Push 50 m, Sled Pull 50 m, Burpee Broad Jumps 80 m, Farmer's Carry 200 m, Lunges 100 m, Wall Balls 100 reps (men) / 100 reps (women). Record time for each. |
| Half Simulation | Race-day readiness | 4 × 1 km run + 4 stations, timed. |
| Full Simulation | Goal pace validation | All 8 × 1 km + 8 stations, timed (every 6–8 weeks max). |

### 4.2 Performance-Based Adjustment Rules

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **PB-1** | 5 km running pace improves >5% at monthly benchmark | Advance to next phase's running intensity targets immediately. E.g., if in General Prep, adopt Specific Prep pace zones. Recalculate all interval paces based on new benchmark. |
| **PB-2** | 5 km running pace regresses >3% at monthly benchmark | Investigate: check ACWR for overtraining spike, review sleep/stress data. If ACWR >1.4 → insert a deload week. If ACWR normal → add 1 additional easy run per week to build aerobic base. Retest in 2 weeks. |
| **PB-3** | Any individual station time stagnates (≤1% improvement) for 4+ weeks | Add a **targeted station intervention block**: 2 additional station-specific sessions per week for 3 weeks (15–20 min each), placed on existing training days as add-ons. Example: if SkiErg stagnates → add 2 × SkiErg-focused sessions (5 × 200 m intervals at RPE 8 with 90-sec rest). |
| **PB-4** | Full simulation time is >15% slower than goal pace | Reassess goal pace — it may be unrealistic. If goal remains valid, shift training emphasis: increase simulation frequency to every 10 days, add 1 half-sim per week, and reduce general strength to maintenance (1×/week). |
| **PB-5** | Full simulation time is within 5% of goal pace with 6+ weeks remaining | Athlete is ahead of schedule. Maintain current approach; do not increase training load unnecessarily. Focus remaining weeks on race-day tactics: pacing, transitions, nutrition strategy. Consider targeting a faster goal if athlete is motivated. |
| **PB-6** | One station time is >20% slower than the athlete's tier-adjusted average | Trigger **Station-Specific Intervention** (see Weakness Identification Matrix below). Dedicate 3 supplemental sessions/week to that station for a 3-week block. |
| **PB-7** | Athlete improves by >10% on a previously weak station after intervention | Return station to normal training frequency. Reallocate supplemental time to the next-weakest station or general conditioning. |

### 4.3 Weakness Identification Matrix

This matrix compares the athlete's individual station times against tier-normative data to compute a **Station Performance Index (SPI)** for each station. SPI = (Athlete's Station Time / Tier Average Station Time) × 100. An SPI of 100 = exactly average for their tier. SPI > 115 = significantly weak. SPI < 90 = relative strength.

**Tier norms** are based on published Hyrox results data and categorized by goal finish time:

| Station | Elite (<70 min) | Competitive (70–85 min) | Intermediate (85–100 min) | Beginner (100–120 min) |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| SkiErg 1,000 m | 3:15 | 3:50 | 4:30 | 5:30 |
| Sled Push 50 m | 1:30 | 2:15 | 3:15 | 4:30 |
| Sled Pull 50 m | 1:20 | 2:00 | 3:00 | 4:15 |
| Burpee Broad Jumps 80 m | 3:00 | 4:00 | 5:30 | 7:00 |
| Row 1,000 m | 3:20 | 3:55 | 4:30 | 5:30 |
| Farmer's Carry 200 m | 1:30 | 2:00 | 2:45 | 3:30 |
| Lunges 100 m | 3:00 | 4:15 | 5:45 | 7:30 |
| Wall Balls 100 reps | 4:00 | 5:30 | 7:00 | 9:00 |

**Interpretation Rules:**

| SPI Range | Classification | AI Coach Action |
|---|---|---|
| SPI < 90 | 🟢 Relative Strength | Maintain current training. No extra work needed. |
| SPI 90–105 | ⚪ On Track | Standard programming. |
| SPI 106–115 | 🟡 Developing Weakness | Add 1 supplemental station drill per week (10–15 min). |
| SPI 116–130 | 🟠 Significant Weakness | Add 2 supplemental station drills per week. Investigate root cause: is it a strength issue (sled), endurance issue (SkiErg/row), or technique issue (burpee broad jumps, wall balls)? |
| SPI > 130 | 🔴 Critical Weakness | Dedicate 3 sessions/week to this station for 3 weeks. Reduce general strength to maintenance. This station becomes the #1 training priority regardless of phase. |

## 5. Environmental & Lifestyle Adaptation

### 5.1 High Stress Week (Work, Life Events)

The AI detects this when the "Life Stress" sub-score in the Readiness Check averages ≤ 4 over 3+ consecutive days.

| Action | Specification |
|---|---|
| Reduce weekly training volume by **25–30%** | Remove the lowest-priority session entirely. Shorten remaining sessions by 15–20%. |
| Reduce high-intensity work by **40%** | Convert 1 HIIT session to Zone 2 cardio. Keep 1 quality session (the most important for current phase). |
| Add recovery modalities | Prescribe 10-min post-session breathwork (box breathing: 4-4-4-4 cadence). Recommend magnesium supplementation and sleep hygiene review. |
| Duration | Maintain modifications until Life Stress score returns to ≥6 for 2+ consecutive days. |

### 5.2 Poor Sleep (<6 Hours)

Detected via Sleep Quality sub-score ≤ 4, or direct athlete report.

| Sleep Duration | Session Modification |
|---|---|
| 5–6 hours (1 night) | Reduce session intensity by 5–10%. Extend warm-up by 5 min. Proceed with caution; monitor mid-session RPE. |
| <5 hours (1 night) | Downgrade session by one Readiness Tier (e.g., Green → Yellow). Cap session RPE at 7. |
| <6 hours for 3+ consecutive nights | Apply Orange-tier modifications to ALL sessions until sleep normalizes. Add 1 rest day. Provide sleep hygiene education: consistent bedtime, no screens 1 hr before bed, cool bedroom (18–20°C), caffeine cutoff by 1:00 PM. |
| <5 hours for 3+ consecutive nights | Red-tier: recovery sessions only until sleep improves. Investigate underlying cause (stress, medical, schedule). |

### 5.3 Traveling (Limited Equipment)

When the athlete flags travel status, the AI serves one of three **travel workout templates** based on available equipment:

#### Hotel Gym (Treadmill + Dumbbells + Cable Machine)

| Day | Session (30–40 min) |
|---|---|
| 1 | Treadmill intervals: 6 × 3 min at threshold pace / 2 min easy. DB lunges 3 × 12/leg. DB farmer's carry 3 × 40 m. |
| 2 | Recovery: 20-min easy treadmill jog + 15-min mobility routine. |
| 3 | DB circuit: 4 rounds of 10 goblet squats, 10 DB push press, 10 DB rows, 15 wall balls (sub: DB thrusters), 200-m treadmill run between rounds. |

#### Bodyweight Only (Hotel Room / Park)

| Day | Session (20–30 min) |
|---|---|
| 1 | AMRAP 20 min: 10 burpee broad jumps, 20 air squats, 15 push-ups, 200-m run (or 40 high knees). |
| 2 | 30-min easy run at conversational pace (outdoor or treadmill). |
| 3 | 4 × 4-min Tabata blocks (20 sec work / 10 sec rest): block 1 = jump squats; block 2 = mountain climbers; block 3 = walking lunges; block 4 = burpees. 2-min rest between blocks. |

#### Minimal Equipment (Resistance Band + Jump Rope)

| Day | Session (25–35 min) |
|---|---|
| 1 | Jump rope intervals: 8 × 1 min fast / 30 sec rest. Band pull-aparts 3 × 20. Band-resisted squats 3 × 15. Band rows 3 × 15. |
| 2 | 25-min easy run + band-assisted stretching 10 min. |
| 3 | Circuit: 5 rounds of 30-sec jump rope sprint, 10 band-resisted lunges per leg, 10 band push-ups, 15 band rows. 60-sec rest between rounds. |

**Travel rule:** No more than 2 consecutive rest days while traveling. If equipment is zero, at minimum perform 20 min of bodyweight movement daily.

### 5.4 Hot Weather Training (>30°C / 86°F)

Supported by Periard et al. (2015, *Sports Med*) heat acclimatization guidelines.

| Adjustment | Specification |
|---|---|
| Reduce running pace by **8–12%** for the first 5 sessions in heat | Allow cardiac drift without chasing normal pace. RPE should guide effort, not GPS pace. |
| Reduce HIIT volume by **20%** for first week in heat | Add 30-sec additional rest between intervals. |
| Hydration protocol | Pre-session: 500 ml water with electrolytes 2 hrs before. During: 200 ml every 15–20 min. Post: 1.5 × body weight lost in fluid. |
| Acclimatization timeline | After 7–10 sessions in heat, begin restoring normal pace/volume in 5% increments per session. Full acclimatization expected by 14 sessions (Racinais et al., 2015). |
| RPE recalibration | Expect RPE to be 1–2 points higher than normal for same workload in heat. Do NOT adjust target RPE downward — use actual RPE to drive autoregulation normally. |

### 5.5 Altitude Training (>1,500 m / 5,000 ft)

| Altitude | Adjustment |
|---|---|
| 1,500–2,000 m | Reduce running pace by 5–8%. Reduce HIIT intensity by 10%. Expect RPE +1 for same effort. Allow 3–5 days for initial acclimatization. |
| 2,000–2,500 m | Reduce running pace by 10–15%. Reduce all high-intensity volume by 20%. Increase hydration by 50%. Allow 7–10 days for acclimatization. Monitor SpO2 if possible. |
| >2,500 m | Reduce all intensity by 15–20%. Limit sessions to 45 min for first 5 days. If SpO2 drops below 88% during exercise → stop and descend. |

### 5.6 Return from Minor Illness Protocol

Based on Elliott et al. (2020, *BJSM*) graduated return-to-play framework and Schwellnus et al. (2016) return-after-infection guidelines. The athlete must be symptom-free for ≥48 hours before beginning this protocol.

| Day Post-Clearance | Session |
|---|---|
| Day 1 | 15-min easy walk + 10-min light stretching/mobility. Target RPE ≤ 3. |
| Day 2 | 20-min easy jog or bike at HR < Zone 1 ceiling (< 65% max HR). Target RPE ≤ 4. |
| Day 3 | 30-min Zone 2 run (RPE 4–5). If RPE ≥ 6 → return to Day 2 protocol for another day. |
| Day 4 | 40-min session at 60% normal volume and 80% normal intensity. Include light strength (bodyweight or 50% normal loads). |
| Day 5 | 50-min session at 75% normal volume, 90% normal intensity. |
| Day 6 | Resume full programming if Readiness Score ≥ 7. If Readiness < 7, repeat Day 5. |

**Hard rule:** If symptoms return at any stage → return to Day 1 and add 48 hours of rest. If fever occurs → medical clearance required before any exercise resumes.

## 6. Communication Templates

The AI coach uses these templates to explain adaptations clearly, building trust and compliance. Every message follows the **"Observation → Reasoning → Action → Reassurance"** framework.

### Template 1: Elevated RPE Pattern

> **"I've noticed your RPE has been higher than expected this week.** Your last 3 sessions averaged RPE 8.2 against a target of 6.5. This tells me your body is accumulating more fatigue than planned — which is totally normal and happens to every athlete.
>
